article:
{{Infobox disease | Name = Biotin deficiency | Image = Biotin structure.svg |
Caption = Biotin | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = | ICD9 = | ICDO = | OMIM = |
MedlinePlus = | eMedicineSubj = ped | eMedicineTopic = 238 | MeshID = | }}
'Biotin deficiency' is a rare nutritional disorder which can become serious,
even fatal, if allowed to progress untreated. It can occur in people of any age,
ancestry, or gender. Biotin is part of the B vitamin family. Biotin deficiency
rarely occurs among healthy people because the daily requirement of biotin is
low, many foods provide adequate amounts of it, intestinal bacteria synthesize
small amounts of it, and the body effectively scavenges and recycles it from
bodily waste. However, deficiencies can be caused by consuming raw egg whites
over a period of months to years. Egg whites contain high levels of avidin, a
protein that binds biotin strongly. When cooked, avidin is partially denatured
and becomes somewhat non-toxic. A recent study found that activity in
fried, poached and boiled (2 min) egg white was 33, 71 and 40% of the activity
in raw egg white respectively.
